Provably Secure Federated Learning against Malicious Clients

Xiaoyu Cao, Jinyuan Jia, Neil Zhenqiang Gong
Abstract

Federated learning enables clients to collaboratively learn a shared global model without sharing their local training data with a cloud server. However, malicious clients can corrupt the global model to predict incorrect labels for testing examples. Existing defenses against malicious clients leverage Byzantine-robust federated learning methods. However, these methods cannot provably guarantee that the predicted label for a testing example is not affected by malicious clients. We bridge this gap via ensemble federated learning. In particular, given any base federated learning algorithm, we use the algorithm to learn multiple global models, each of which is learnt using a randomly selected subset of clients. When predicting the label of a testing example, we take majority vote among the global models. We show that our ensemble federated learning with any base federated learning algorithm is provably secure against malicious clients. Specifically, the label predicted by our ensemble global model for a testing example is provably not affected by a bounded number of malicious clients. Moreover, we show that our derived bound is tight. We evaluate our method on MNIST and Human Activity Recognition datasets. For instance, our method can achieve a certified accuracy of 88% on MNIST when 20 out of 1,000 clients are malicious.

Introduction

Federated learning (Konečnỳ et al. 2016; McMahan et al. 2017) is an emerging machine learning paradigm, which enables many clients (e.g., smartphones, IoT devices, and organizations) to collaboratively learn a model without sharing their local training data with a cloud server. Due to its promise for protecting privacy of the clients’ local training data and the emerging privacy regulations such as General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), federated learning has been deployed by industry. For instance, Google has deployed federated learning for next-word prediction on Android Gboard. Existing federated learning methods mainly follow a single-global-model paradigm. Specifically, a cloud server maintains a global model and each client maintains a local model. The global model is trained via multiple iterations of communications between the clients and server. In each iteration, three steps are performed: 1) the server sends the current global model to the clients; 2) the clients update their local models based on the global model and their local training data, and send the model updates to the server; and 3) the server aggregates the model updates and uses them to update the global model. The learnt global model is then used to predict labels of testing examples.

However, such single-global-model paradigm is vulnerable to security attacks. In particular, an attacker can inject fake clients to federated learning or compromise existing clients, where we call the fake/compromised clients malicious clients. Such malicious clients can corrupt the global model via carefully tampering their local training data or model updates sent to the server. As a result, the corrupted global model has a low accuracy for the normal testing examples (Fang et al. 2020; Xie, Koyejo, and Gupta 2019) or certain attacker-chosen testing examples (Bagdasaryan et al. 2020; Bhagoji et al. 2019; Xie et al. 2020). For instance, when learning an image classifier, the malicious clients can re-label the cars with certain strips as birds in their local training data and scale up their model updates sent to the server, such that the learnt global model incorrectly predicts a car with the strips as bird (Bagdasaryan et al. 2020).

Various Byzantine-robust federated learning methods have been proposed to defend against malicious clients (Blanchard et al. 2017; Chen, Su, and Xu 2017; Mhamdi, Guerraoui, and Rouault 2018; Yin et al. 2018, 2019; Chen et al. 2018; Alistarh, Allen-Zhu, and Li 2018). The main idea of these methods is to mitigate the impact of statistical outliers among the clients’ model updates. They can bound the difference between the global model parameters learnt without malicious clients and the global model parameters learnt when some clients become malicious. However, these methods cannot provably guarantee that the label predicted by the global model for a testing example is not affected by malicious clients. Indeed, studies showed that malicious clients can still substantially degrade the testing accuracy of a global model learnt by a Byzantine-robust method via carefully tampering their model updates sent to the server (Bhagoji et al. 2019; Fang et al. 2020; Xie, Koyejo, and Gupta 2019).

In this work, we propose ensemble federated learning, the first federated learning method that is provably secure against malicious clients. Specifically, given n𝑛n clients, we define a subsample as a set of k𝑘k clients sampled from the n𝑛n clients uniformly at random without replacement. For each subsample, we can learn a global model using a base federated learning algorithm with the k𝑘k clients in the subsample. Since there are (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} subsamples with k𝑘k clients, (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models can be trained in total. Suppose we are given a testing example 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. We define pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} as the fraction of the (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models that predict label i𝑖i for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, where i=1,2,⋯,L𝑖12⋯𝐿i=1,2,\cdots,L. We call pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} label probability. Our ensemble global model predicts the label with the largest label probability for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. In other words, our ensemble global model takes a majority vote among the global models to predict label for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. Since each global model is learnt using a subsample with k𝑘k clients, a majority of the global models are learnt using normal clients when most clients are normal. Therefore, the majority vote among the global models is secure against a bounded number of malicious clients.

Theory:  Our first major theoretical result is that our ensemble global model provably predicts the same label for a testing example 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} when the number of malicious clients is no larger than a threshold, which we call certified security level. Our second major theoretical result is that we prove our derived certified security level is tight, i.e., when no assumptions are made on the base federated learning algorithm, it is impossible to derive a certified security level that is larger than ours. Note that the certified security level may be different for different testing examples.

Algorithm:  Computing our certified security level for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} requires its largest and second largest label probabilities. When (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is small (e.g., the n𝑛n clients are dozens of organizations (Kairouz et al. 2019) and k𝑘k is small), we can compute the largest and second largest label probabilities exactly via training (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models. However, it is challenging to compute them exactly when (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is large. To address the computational challenge, we develop a Monte Carlo algorithm to estimate them with probabilistic guarantees via training N𝑁N instead of (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models.

Evaluation:  We empirically evaluate our method on MNIST (LeCun, Cortes, and Burges 1998) and Human Activity Recognition datasets (Anguita et al. 2013). We distribute the training examples in MNIST to clients to simulate federated learning scenarios, while the Human Activity Recognition dataset represents a real-world federated learning scenario, where each user is a client. We use the popular FedAvg developed by Google (McMahan et al. 2017) as the base federated learning algorithm. Moreover, we use certified accuracy as our evaluation metric, which is a lower bound of the testing accuracy that a method can provably achieve no matter how the malicious clients tamper their local training data and model updates. For instance, our ensemble FedAvg with N=500𝑁500N=500 and k=10𝑘10k=10 can achieve a certified accuracy of 88% on MNIST when evenly distributing the training examples among 1,000 clients and 20 of them are malicious.

In summary, our key contributions are as follows:

  • •

    Theory: We propose ensemble federated learning, the first provably secure federated learning method against malicious clients. We derive a certified security level for our ensemble federated learning. Moreover, we prove that our derived certified security level is tight.

  • •

    Algorithm: We propose a Monte Carlo algorithm to compute our certified security level in practice.

  • •

    Evaluation: We evaluate our methods on MNIST and Human Activity Recognition datasets.

All our proofs are shown in Supplemental Material.

Background on Federated Learning

Assuming we have n𝑛n clients 𝐂={1,2,⋯,n}𝐂12⋯𝑛\mathbf{C}=\{1,2,\cdots,n\} and a cloud server in a federated learning setting. The i𝑖ith client holds some local training dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, where i=1,2,⋯,n𝑖12⋯𝑛i=1,2,\cdots,n. Existing federated learning methods (Konečnỳ et al. 2016; McMahan et al. 2017; Wang et al. 2020; Li et al. 2020b) mainly focus on learning a single global model for the n𝑛n clients. Specifically, the server maintains a global model and each client maintains a local model. Then, federated learning iteratively performs the following three steps, which are shown in Algorithm 1. In Step I, the server sends the current global model to the clients.111The server may select a subset of clients, but we assume the server sends the global model to all clients for convenience. In Step II, each client trains a local model via fine-tuning the global model to its local training dataset. In particular, each client performs localIter iterations of stochastic gradient descent with a learning rate η𝜂\eta to train its local model. Then, each client sends its model update (i.e., the difference between the local model and the global model) to the server. In Step III, the server aggregates the clients’ model updates according to some aggregation rule Agg and uses the aggregated model update to update the global model. The three steps are repeated for globalIter iterations. Existing federated learning algorithms essentially use different aggregation rules in Step III. For instance, Google developed FedAvg (McMahan et al. 2017), which computes the average of the clients’ model updates weighted by the sizes of their local training datasets as the aggregated model update to update the global model.

We call such a federated learning algorithm that learns a single global model base federated learning algorithm and denote it as 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Note that given any subset of the n𝑛n clients 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C}, a base federated learning algorithm can learn a global model for them. Specifically, the server learns a global model via iteratively performing the three steps between the server and the given subset of clients.

Our Ensemble Federated Learning

Unlike single-global-model federated learning, our ensemble federated learning trains multiple global models, each of which is trained using the base algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and a subsample with k𝑘k clients sampled from the n𝑛n clients uniformly at random without replacement. Among the n𝑛n clients 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C}, we have (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} subsamples with k𝑘k clients. Therefore, (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models can be trained in total if we train a global model using each subsample. For a given testing input 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, these global models may predict different labels for it. We define pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} as the fraction of the (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models that predict label i𝑖i for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, where i=1,2,⋯,L𝑖12⋯𝐿i=1,2,\cdots,L. We call pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} label probability. Note that pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is an integer multiplication of 1(nk)1binomial𝑛𝑘\frac{1}{{n\choose k}}, which we will leverage to derive a tight security guarantee of ensemble federated learning. Moreover, pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} can also be viewed as the probability that a global model trained on a random subsample with k𝑘k clients predicts label i𝑖i for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. Our ensemble global model predicts the label with the largest label probability for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, i.e., we define:

h​(𝐂,𝐱)=argmaxipi,ℎ𝐂𝐱subscriptargmax𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖h(\mathbf{C},\mathbf{x})=\operatornamewithlimits{argmax}_{i}p_{i}, (1)

where hℎh is our ensemble global model and h​(𝐂,𝐱)ℎ𝐂𝐱h(\mathbf{C},\mathbf{x}) is the label that our ensemble global model predicts for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} when the ensemble global model is trained on clients 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C}.

Defining provable security guarantees against malicious clients:  Suppose some of the n𝑛n clients 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} become malicious. These malicious clients can arbitrarily tamper their local training data and model updates sent to the server in each iteration of federated learning. We denote by 𝐂′superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C}^{\prime} the set of n𝑛n clients with malicious ones. Moreover, we denote by M​(𝐂′)𝑀superscript𝐂′M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime}) the number of malicious clients in 𝐂′superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C}^{\prime}, e.g., M​(𝐂′)=m𝑀superscript𝐂′𝑚M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})=m means that m𝑚m clients are malicious. Note that we don’t know which clients are malicious. For a testing example 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, our goal is to show that our ensemble global model hℎh provably predicts the same label for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} when the number of malicious clients is bounded. Formally, we aim to show the following:

h​(𝐂′,𝐱)=h​(𝐂,𝐱),∀𝐂′,M​(𝐂′)≤m∗,formulae-sequenceℎsuperscript𝐂′𝐱ℎ𝐂𝐱for-allsuperscript𝐂′𝑀superscript𝐂′superscript𝑚\displaystyle h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x})=h(\mathbf{C},\mathbf{x}),\forall\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq m^{*}, (2)

where h​(𝐂′,𝐱)ℎsuperscript𝐂′𝐱h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}) is the label that the ensemble global model trained on the clients 𝐂′superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C}^{\prime} predicts for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. We call m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} certified security level. When a global model satisfies Equation (2) for a testing example 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, we say the global model achieves a provable security guarantee for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} with a certified security level m∗superscript𝑚m^{*}. Note that the certified security level may be different for different testing examples. Next, we derive the certified security level of our ensemble global model.

Deriving certified security level using approximate label probabilities:  When (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is small (e.g., several hundred), we can compute the exact label probabilities pysubscript𝑝𝑦p_{y} and pzsubscript𝑝𝑧p_{z} via training (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models, and compute the certified security level via inequality (3). However, when (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is large, it is computationally challenging to compute the exact label probabilities via training (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models. The following theorem formally summarizes our certified security level.

Theorem 1.

Given n𝑛n clients 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C}, an arbitrary base federated learning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, a subsample size k𝑘k, and a testing example 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, we define an ensemble global model hℎh as Equation (1). y𝑦y and z𝑧z are the labels that have the largest and second largest label probabilities for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} in the ensemble global model. py¯¯subscript𝑝𝑦\underline{p_{y}} is a lower bound of pysubscript𝑝𝑦p_{y} and p¯zsubscript¯𝑝𝑧\overline{p}_{z} is an upper bound of pzsubscript𝑝𝑧p_{z}. Formally, py¯¯subscript𝑝𝑦\underline{p_{y}} and p¯zsubscript¯𝑝𝑧\overline{p}_{z} satisfy the following conditions:

maxi≠y⁡pi=pz≤p¯z≤py¯≤py.subscript𝑖𝑦subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑧subscript¯𝑝𝑧¯subscript𝑝𝑦subscript𝑝𝑦\max_{i\neq y}p_{i}=p_{z}\leq\overline{p}_{z}\leq\underline{p_{y}}\leq p_{y}. (6)

Then, hℎh provably predicts y𝑦y for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} when at most m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} clients in 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} become malicious, i.e., we have:

h​(𝐂′,𝐱)=h​(𝐂,𝐱)=y,∀𝐂′,M​(𝐂′)≤m∗,formulae-sequenceℎsuperscript𝐂′𝐱ℎ𝐂𝐱𝑦for-allsuperscript𝐂′𝑀superscript𝐂′superscript𝑚\displaystyle\;h(\mathbf{C^{\prime}},\mathbf{x})=h(\mathbf{C},\mathbf{x})=y,\forall\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq m^{*}, (7)

where m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} is the largest integer m𝑚m (0≤m≤n−k0𝑚𝑛𝑘0\leq m\leq n-k) that satisfies inequality (5).

Our Theorem 1 is applicable to any base federated learning algorithm, any lower bound py¯¯subscript𝑝𝑦\underline{p_{y}} of pysubscript𝑝𝑦p_{y} and any upper bound p¯zsubscript¯𝑝𝑧\overline{p}_{z} of pzsubscript𝑝𝑧p_{z} that satisfy (6). When the lower bound py¯¯subscript𝑝𝑦\underline{p_{y}} and upper bound p¯zsubscript¯𝑝𝑧\overline{p}_{z} are estimated more accurately, i.e., py¯¯subscript𝑝𝑦\underline{p_{y}} and p¯zsubscript¯𝑝𝑧\overline{p}_{z} are respectively closer to pysubscript𝑝𝑦p_{y} and pzsubscript𝑝𝑧p_{z}, our certified security level may be larger. The following theorem shows that our derived certified security level is tight, i.e., when no assumptions on the base federated learning algorithm are made, it is impossible to derive a certified security level that is larger than ours for the given probability bounds py¯¯subscript𝑝𝑦\underline{p_{y}} and p¯zsubscript¯𝑝𝑧\overline{p}_{z}.

Theorem 2.

Suppose py¯+p¯z≤1¯subscript𝑝𝑦subscript¯𝑝𝑧1\underline{p_{y}}+\overline{p}_{z}\leq 1. For any 𝐂′superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C^{\prime}} satisfying M​(𝐂′)>m∗𝑀superscript𝐂′superscript𝑚M(\mathbf{C^{\prime}})>m^{*}, i.e., at least m∗+1superscript𝑚1m^{*}+1 clients are malicious, there exists a base federated learning algorithm 𝒜∗superscript𝒜\mathcal{A}^{*} that satisfies (6) but h​(𝐂′,𝐱)≠yℎsuperscript𝐂′𝐱𝑦h(\mathbf{C^{\prime}},\mathbf{x})\neq y or there exist ties.

Computing the Certified Security Level

Suppose we are given n𝑛n clients 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C}, a base federated learning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, a subsample size k𝑘k, and a testing dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} with d𝑑d testing examples. For each testing example 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t} in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, we aim to compute its label y^tsubscript^𝑦𝑡\hat{y}_{t} predicted by our ensemble global model hℎh and the corresponding certified security level m^t∗superscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡\hat{m}_{t}^{*}. To compute the certified security level based on our Theorem 1, we need a lower bound py^t¯¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} of the largest label probability py^tsubscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} and an upper bound p¯z^tsubscript¯𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} of the second largest label probability pz^tsubscript𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}. When (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is small, we can compute the exact label probabilities via training (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models. When (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is large, we propose a Monte Carlo algorithm to estimate the predicted label and the two probability bounds for all testing examples in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} simultaneously with a confidence level 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha via training N𝑁N of the (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models.

Computing predicted label and probability bounds for one testing example:  We first discuss how to compute the predicted label y^tsubscript^𝑦𝑡\hat{y}_{t} and probability bounds py^t¯¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} and p¯z^tsubscript¯𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} for one testing example 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}. We sample N𝑁N subsamples with k𝑘k clients from the n𝑛n clients uniformly at random without replacement and use them to train N𝑁N global models g1,g2,⋯,gNsubscript𝑔1subscript𝑔2⋯subscript𝑔𝑁g_{1},g_{2},\cdots,g_{N}. We use the N𝑁N global models to predict labels for 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t} and count the frequency of each label. We treat the label with the largest frequency as the predicted label y^tsubscript^𝑦𝑡\hat{y}_{t}. Recall that, based on the definition of label probability, a global model trained on a random subsample with k𝑘k clients predicts label y^tsubscript^𝑦𝑡\hat{y}_{t} for 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t} with the label probability py^tsubscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡p_{\hat{y}_{t}}. Therefore, the frequency Ny^tsubscript𝑁subscript^𝑦𝑡N_{\hat{y}_{t}} of the label y^tsubscript^𝑦𝑡\hat{y}_{t} among the N𝑁N global models follows a binomial distribution B​(N,py^t)𝐵𝑁subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡B(N,p_{\hat{y}_{t}}) with parameters N𝑁N and py^tsubscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡p_{\hat{y}_{t}}. Thus, given Ny^tsubscript𝑁subscript^𝑦𝑡N_{\hat{y}_{t}} and N𝑁N, we can use the standard one-sided Clopper-Pearson method (Clopper and Pearson 1934) to estimate a lower bound py^t¯¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} of py^tsubscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} with a confidence level 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha. Specifically, we have py^t¯=ℬ​(α;Ny^t,N−Ny^t+1)¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡ℬ𝛼subscript𝑁subscript^𝑦𝑡𝑁subscript𝑁subscript^𝑦𝑡1\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}=\mathcal{B}\left({\alpha};N_{\hat{y}_{t}},N-N_{\hat{y}_{t}}+1\right), where ℬ​(q;v,w)ℬ𝑞𝑣𝑤\mathcal{B}(q;v,w) is the q𝑞qth quantile from a beta distribution with shape parameters v𝑣v and w𝑤w. Moreover, we can estimate p¯z^t=1−py^t¯≥1−py^t≥pztsubscript¯𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡1¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡1subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡subscript𝑝subscript𝑧𝑡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}=1-\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}\geq 1-p_{\hat{y}_{t}}\geq{p}_{z_{t}} as an upper bound of pz^tsubscript𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}.

Computing predicted labels and probability bounds for d𝑑d testing examples:  One method to compute the predicted labels and probability bounds for the d𝑑d testing examples is to apply the above process to each testing example individually. However, such method is computationally intractable because it requires training N𝑁N global models for every testing example. To address the computational challenge, we propose a method that only needs to train N𝑁N global models in total. Our idea is to split α𝛼\alpha among the d𝑑d testing examples. Specifically, we follow the above process to train N𝑁N global models and use them to predict labels for the d𝑑d testing examples. For each testing example 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}, we estimate the lower bound py^t¯=ℬ​(αd;Ny^t,N−Ny^t+1)¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡ℬ𝛼𝑑subscript𝑁subscript^𝑦𝑡𝑁subscript𝑁subscript^𝑦𝑡1\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}=\mathcal{B}\left(\frac{\alpha}{d};N_{\hat{y}_{t}},N-N_{\hat{y}_{t}}+1\right) with confidence level 1−α/d1𝛼𝑑1-\alpha/d instead of 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha. According to the Bonferroni correction, the simultaneous confidence level of estimating the lower bounds for the d𝑑d testing examples is 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha. Following the above process, we still estimate p¯z^t=1−py^t¯subscript¯𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡1¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}=1-\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} as an upper bound of pz^tsubscript𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} for each testing example.

Complete algorithm: Algorithm 2 shows our algorithm to compute the predicted labels and certified security levels for the d𝑑d testing examples in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. The function Sample&Train randomly samples N𝑁N subsamples with k𝑘k clients and trains N𝑁N global models using the base federated learning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Given the probability bounds py^t¯¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} and p¯z^tsubscript¯𝑝subscript^𝑧𝑡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} for a testing example 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}, the function SearchLevel finds the certified security level m^t∗superscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡\hat{m}_{t}^{*} via finding the largest integer m𝑚m that satisfies (5). For example, SearchLevel can simply start m𝑚m from 0 and iteratively increase it by one until finding m^t∗superscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡\hat{m}_{t}^{*}.

Probabilistic guarantees: In Algorithm 2, since we estimate the lower bound py^t¯¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} using the Clopper-Pearson method, there is a probability that the estimated lower bound is incorrect, i.e., py^t¯>py^t¯subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡subscript𝑝subscript^𝑦𝑡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}>p_{\hat{y}_{t}}. When the lower bound is estimated incorrectly for a testing example 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}, the certified security level m^t∗superscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡\hat{m}_{t}^{*} outputted by Algorithm 2 for 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t} may also be incorrect, i.e., there may exist an 𝐂′superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C}^{\prime} such that M​(𝐂′)≤m^t∗𝑀superscript𝐂′superscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*} but h​(𝐂′,𝐱t)≠y^tℎsuperscript𝐂′subscript𝐱𝑡subscript^𝑦𝑡h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})\neq\hat{y}_{t}. In other words, our Algorithm 2 has probabilistic guarantees for its outputted certified security levels. However, in the following theorem, we prove the probability that Algorithm 2 returns an incorrect certified security level for at least one testing example is at most α𝛼\alpha.

Theorem 3.

The probability that Algorithm 2 returns an incorrect certified security level for at least one testing example in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is bounded by α𝛼\alpha, which is equivalent to:

Pr (∩𝐱t∈𝒟(h​(𝐂′,𝐱t)=y^t,∀𝐂′,M​(𝐂′)≤m^t∗|y^t≠ABSTAIN))subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝒟formulae-sequenceℎsuperscript𝐂′subscript𝐱𝑡subscript^𝑦𝑡for-allsuperscript𝐂′𝑀superscript𝐂′conditionalsuperscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡subscript^𝑦𝑡ABSTAIN\displaystyle(\cap_{\mathbf{x}_{t}\in\mathcal{D}}(h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})=\hat{y}_{t},\forall\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*}|\hat{y}_{t}\neq\text{ABSTAIN}))
≥1−α.absent1𝛼\displaystyle\geq 1-\alpha. (8)

Note that when the probability bounds are estimated deterministically, e.g., when (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is small and the exact label probabilities can be computed via training (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models, the certified security level obtained from our Theorem 1 is also deterministic.

Experiments

Experimental Setup

Datasets, model architectures, and base algorithm: We use MNIST (LeCun, Cortes, and Burges 1998) and Human Activity Recognition (HAR) datasets (Anguita et al. 2013). MNIST is used to simulate federated learning scenarios, while HAR represents a real-world federated learning scenario. Specifically, MNIST has 60,000 training examples and 10,000 testing examples. We consider n=1,000𝑛1000n=1,000 clients and we split them into 101010 groups. We assign a training example with label l𝑙l to the l𝑙lth group of clients with probability q𝑞q and assign it to each remaining group with a probability 1−q91𝑞9\frac{1-q}{9}. After assigning a training example to a group, we distribute it to a client in the group uniformly at random. The parameter q𝑞q controls local training data distribution on clients and we call q𝑞q degree of non-IID. q=0.1𝑞0.1q=0.1 means that clients’ local training data are IID, while a larger q𝑞q indicates a larger degree of non-IID. By default, we set q=0.5𝑞0.5q=0.5. However, we will study the impact of q𝑞q (degree of non-IID) on our method. HAR includes human activity data from 30 users, each of which is a client. The task is to predict a user’s activity based on the sensor signals (e.g., acceleration) collected from the user’s smartphone. There are 6 possible activities (e.g., walking, sitting, and standing), indicating a 6-class classification problem. There are 10,299 examples in total and each example has 561 features. We use 75% of each user’s examples as training examples and the rest as testing examples.

We consider a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture (shown in Supplemental Material) for MNIST. For HAR, we consider a deep neural network (DNN) with two fully-connected hidden layers, each of which contains 256 neurons and uses ReLU as the activation function. We use the popular FedAvg (McMahan et al. 2017) as the base federated learning algorithm. Recall that a base federated learning algorithm has hyperparameters (shown in Algorithm 1): g​l​o​b​a​l​I​t​e​r𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝐼𝑡𝑒𝑟globalIter, l​o​c​a​l​I​t​e​r𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝐼𝑡𝑒𝑟localIter, learning rate η𝜂\eta, and batch size. Table 1 summarizes these hyperparameters for FedAvg in our experiments. In particular, we set the g​l​o​b​a​l​I​t​e​r𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝐼𝑡𝑒𝑟globalIter in Table 1 because FedAvg converges with such settings.

Evaluation metric: We use certified accuracy as our evaluation metric. Specifically, we define the certified accuracy at m𝑚m malicious clients (denoted as CA@​m@𝑚@m) for a federated learning method as the fraction of testing examples in the testing dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} whose labels are correctly predicted by the method and whose certified security levels are at least m𝑚m. Formally, we define CA@​m@𝑚@m as follows:

CA​@​m=∑𝐱t∈𝒟𝕀​(y^t=yt)⋅𝕀​(m^t∗≥m)|𝒟|,CA@𝑚subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝒟⋅𝕀subscript^𝑦𝑡subscript𝑦𝑡𝕀superscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡𝑚𝒟\displaystyle\text{CA}@m=\frac{\sum_{\mathbf{x}_{t}\in\mathcal{D}}\mathbb{I}(\hat{y}_{t}=y_{t})\cdot\mathbb{I}(\hat{m}_{t}^{*}\geq m)}{|\mathcal{D}|}, (9)

where 𝕀𝕀\mathbb{I} is the indicator function, ytsubscript𝑦𝑡y_{t} is the true label for 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}, and y^tsubscript^𝑦𝑡\hat{y}_{t} and m^t∗superscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑡\hat{m}_{t}^{*} are respectively the predicted label and certified security level for 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}. Intuitively, CA@​m@𝑚@m means that when at most m𝑚m clients are malicious, the accuracy of the federated learning method for 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is at least CA@​m@𝑚@m no matter what attacks the malicious clients use (i.e., no matter how the malicious clients tamper their local training data and model updates). Note that CA@​0@0@0 reduces to the standard accuracy when there are no malicious clients.

When we can compute the exact label probabilities via training (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} global models, the CA@​m@𝑚@m of our ensemble global model hℎh computed using the certified security levels derived from Theorem 1 is deterministic. When (nk)binomial𝑛𝑘{n\choose k} is large, we estimate predicted labels and certified security levels using Algorithm 2, and thus our CA@​m@𝑚@m has a confidence level 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha according to Theorem 3.

Parameter settings: Our method has three parameters: N𝑁N, k𝑘k, and α𝛼\alpha. Unless otherwise mentioned, we adopt the following default settings for them: N=500𝑁500N=500, α=0.001𝛼0.001\alpha=0.001, k=10𝑘10k=10 for MNIST, and k=2𝑘2k=2 for HAR. Under such default setting for HAR, we have (nk)=(302)=435<N=500binomial𝑛𝑘binomial302435𝑁500{n\choose k}={30\choose 2}=435<N=500 and we can compute the exact label probabilities via training 435 global models. Therefore, we have deterministic certified accuracy for HAR under the default setting. We will explore the impact of each parameter while using the default settings for the other two parameters. For HAR, we set k=4𝑘4k=4 when exploring the impact of N𝑁N (i.e., Figure 4(b)) and α𝛼\alpha (i.e., Figure 5(b)) since the default setting k=2𝑘2k=2 gives deterministic certified accuracy, making N𝑁N and α𝛼\alpha not relevant.

Experimental Results

Single-global-model FedAvg vs. ensemble FedAvg: Figure 2 compares single-global-model FedAvg and ensemble FedAvg with respect to certified accuracy on the two datasets. When there are no malicious clients (i.e., m=0𝑚0m=0), single-global-model FedAvg is more accurate than ensemble FedAvg. This is because ensemble FedAvg uses a subsample of clients to train each global model. However, single-global-model FedAvg has 0 certified accuracy when just one client is malicious. This is because a single malicious client can arbitrarily manipulate the global model learnt by FedAvg (Blanchard et al. 2017). However, the certified accuracy of ensemble FedAvg reduces to 0 when up to 61 and 9 clients (6.1% and 30%) are malicious on MNIST and HAR, respectively. Note that it is unknown whether existing Byzantine-robust federated learning methods have non-zero certified accuracy when m>0𝑚0m>0, and thus we cannot compare ensemble FedAvg with them.

Impact of k𝑘k, N𝑁N, and α𝛼\alpha:  Figure 3, 4, and 5 show the impact of k𝑘k, N𝑁N, and α𝛼\alpha, respectively. k𝑘k achieves a trade-off between accuracy under no malicious clients and security under malicious clients. Specifically, when k𝑘k is larger, the ensemble global model is more accurate at m=0𝑚0m=0, but the certified accuracy drops more quickly to 0 as m𝑚m increases. This is because when k𝑘k is larger, it is more likely for the sampled k𝑘k clients to include malicious ones. The certified accuracy increases as N𝑁N or α𝛼\alpha increases. This is because training more global models or a larger α𝛼\alpha allows Algorithm 2 to estimate tighter probability bounds and larger certified security levels. When N𝑁N increases from 100 to 500, the certified accuracy increases significantly. However, when N𝑁N further grows to 1,000, the increase of certified accuracy is marginal. Our results show that we don’t need to train too many global models in practice, as the certified accuracy saturates when N𝑁N is larger than some threshold.

Impact of degree of non-IID q𝑞q:  Figure 6 shows the certified accuracy of our ensemble FedAvg on MNIST when the clients’ local training data have different degrees of non-IID. We observe that the certified accuracy drops when q𝑞q increases from 0.5 to 0.9, which represents a high degree of non-IID. However, the certified accuracy is still high when m𝑚m is small for q=0.9𝑞0.9q=0.9, e.g., the certified accuracy is still 83% when m=10𝑚10m=10. This is because although each global model trained using a subsample of clients is less accurate when the local training data are highly non-IID, the ensemble of multiple global models is still accurate.

Related Work

In federated learning, the first category of studies (Smith et al. 2017; Li et al. 2020b; Wang et al. 2020; Liu et al. 2020; Peng et al. 2020) aim to design federated learning methods that can learn more accurate global models and/or analyze their convergence properties. For instance, FedMA (Wang et al. 2020) constructs the global model via matching and averaging the hidden elements in a neural network with similar feature extraction signatures. The second category of studies (Konečnỳ et al. 2016; McMahan et al. 2017; Wen et al. 2017; Alistarh et al. 2017; Lee et al. 2017; Sahu et al. 2018; Bernstein et al. 2018; Vogels, Karimireddy, and Jaggi 2019; Yurochkin et al. 2019; Mohri, Sivek, and Suresh 2019; Wang et al. 2020; Li, Wen, and He 2020; Li et al. 2020c; Hamer, Mohri, and Suresh 2020; Rothchild et al. 2020; Malinovsky et al. 2020) aim to improve the communication efficiency between the clients and server via sparsification, quantization, and/or encoding of the model updates sent from the clients to the server. The third category of studies (Bonawitz et al. 2017; Geyer, Klein, and Nabi 2017; Hitaj, Ateniese, and Perez-Cruz 2017; Melis et al. 2019; Zhu, Liu, and Han 2019; Mohri, Sivek, and Suresh 2019; Wang, Tong, and Shi 2020; Li et al. 2020a) aim to explore the privacy/fairness issues of federated learning and their defenses.These studies often assume a single global model is shared among the clients. Smith et al. (Smith et al. 2017) proposed to learn a customized model for each client via multi-task learning.

Our work is on security of federated learning, which is orthogonal to the studies above. Multiple studies (Fang et al. 2020; Bagdasaryan et al. 2020; Xie, Koyejo, and Gupta 2019; Bhagoji et al. 2019) showed that the global model’s accuracy can be significantly downgraded by malicious clients. Existing defenses against malicious clients leverage Byzantine-robust aggregation rules such as Krum (Blanchard et al. 2017), trimmed mean (Yin et al. 2018), coordinate-wise median (Yin et al. 2018), and Bulyan (Mhamdi, Guerraoui, and Rouault 2018). However, they cannot provably guarantee that the global model’s predicted label for a testing example is not affected by malicious clients. As a result, they may be broken by strong attacks that carefully craft the model updates sent from the malicious clients to the server, e.g., (Fang et al. 2020). We propose ensemble federated learning whose predicted label for a testing example is provably not affected by a bounded number of malicious clients.

We note that ensemble methods were also proposed as provably secure defenses (e.g., (Jia, Cao, and Gong 2020)) against data poisoning attacks. However, they are insufficient to defend against malicious clients that can manipulate both the local training data and the model updates. In particular, a provably secure defense against data poisoning attacks guarantees that the label predicted for a testing example is unaffected by a bounded number of poisoned training examples. However, a single malicious client can poison an arbitrary number of its local training examples, breaking the assumption of provably secure defenses against data poisoning attacks.

Conclusion

In this work, we propose ensemble federated learning and derive its tight provable security guarantee against malicious clients. Moreover, we propose an algorithm to compute the certified security levels. Our empirical results on two datasets show that our ensemble federated learning can effectively defend against malicious clients with provable security guarantees. Interesting future work includes estimating the probability bounds deterministically and considering the internal structure of a base federated learning algorithm to further improve our provable security guarantees.

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 1

We first define a subsample of k𝑘k clients from 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} as 𝒮​(𝐂,k)𝒮𝐂𝑘\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C},k). Then, we define the space of all possible subsamples from 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} as 𝐎C={𝒮​(𝐂,k)}subscript𝐎𝐶𝒮𝐂𝑘\mathbf{O}_{C}=\{\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C},k)\} and the space of all possible subsamples from 𝐂′superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C}^{\prime} as 𝐎C′={𝒮​(𝐂′,k)}superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′𝒮superscript𝐂′𝑘\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}=\{\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},k)\}. Let 𝐎o={𝒮​(𝐂∩𝐂′,k)}=𝐎C∩𝐎C′subscript𝐎𝑜𝒮𝐂superscript𝐂′𝑘subscript𝐎𝐶superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′\mathbf{O}_{o}=\{\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C}\cap\mathbf{C}^{\prime},k)\}=\mathbf{O}_{C}\cap\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime} denote the space of all possible subsamples from the set of normal clients 𝐂∩𝐂′𝐂superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C}\cap\mathbf{C}^{\prime}, and 𝐎={𝒮​(𝐂∪𝐂′,k)}=𝐎C∪𝐎C′𝐎𝒮𝐂superscript𝐂′𝑘subscript𝐎𝐶superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′\mathbf{O}=\{\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C}\cup\mathbf{C}^{\prime},k)\}=\mathbf{O}_{C}\cup\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime} denote the space of all possible subsamples from either 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} or 𝐂′superscript𝐂′\mathbf{C}^{\prime}. Figure 7 illustrates 𝐎C,𝐎C′subscript𝐎𝐶superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′\mathbf{O}_{C},\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}, and 𝐎osubscript𝐎𝑜\mathbf{O}_{o}. We use a random variable 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} to denote a subsample 𝒮​(𝐂,k)𝒮𝐂𝑘\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C},k) and 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} to denote a subsample 𝒮​(𝐂′,k)𝒮superscript𝐂′𝑘\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},k) in 𝐎𝐎\mathbf{O}. We know that 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} have the following probability distributions:

Pr​(𝐗=s)={1(nk), if ​s∈𝐎C0, otherwise,Pr𝐗𝑠cases1binomial𝑛𝑘 if 𝑠subscript𝐎𝐶0 otherwise\displaystyle\text{Pr}(\mathbf{X}=s)=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{{n\choose k}},&\text{ if }s\in\mathbf{O}_{C}\\ 0,&\text{ otherwise},\end{cases} (10)

Recall that given a set of clients s𝑠s, the base federated learning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} learns a global model. For simplicity, we denote by 𝒜​(s,𝐱)𝒜𝑠𝐱\mathcal{A}(s,\mathbf{x}) the predicted label of a testing example 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} given by this global model. We have the following equations:

(15)

Note that we have:

Pr​(𝒜​(𝐗,𝐱)=y|𝐗∈𝐎o)=Pr​(𝒜​(𝐘,𝐱)=y|𝐘∈𝐎o),Pr𝒜𝐗𝐱conditional𝑦𝐗subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝒜𝐘𝐱conditional𝑦𝐘subscript𝐎𝑜\displaystyle\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{X}\in\mathbf{O}_{o})=\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{Y}\in\mathbf{O}_{o}), (16)

where m𝑚m is the number of malicious clients. Therefore, we know:

Pr​(𝒜​(𝐗,𝐱)=y|𝐗∈𝐎o)⋅Pr​(𝐗∈𝐎o)=Pr​(𝒜​(𝐘,𝐱)=y|𝐘∈𝐎o)⋅Pr​(𝐘∈𝐎o).⋅Pr𝒜𝐗𝐱conditional𝑦𝐗subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝐗subscript𝐎𝑜⋅Pr𝒜𝐘𝐱conditional𝑦𝐘subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝐘subscript𝐎𝑜\displaystyle\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{X}\in\mathbf{O}_{o})\cdot\text{Pr}(\mathbf{X}\in\mathbf{O}_{o})=\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{Y}\in\mathbf{O}_{o})\cdot\text{Pr}(\mathbf{Y}\in\mathbf{O}_{o}). (18)

By subtracting (13) from (A), we obtain:

py′−pysuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑦′subscript𝑝𝑦\displaystyle p_{y}^{\prime}-p_{y} =Pr​(𝒜​(𝐘,𝐱)=y|𝐘∈(𝐎C′−𝐎o))⋅Pr​(𝐘∈(𝐎C′−𝐎o))absent⋅Pr𝒜𝐘𝐱conditional𝑦𝐘superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝐘superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′subscript𝐎𝑜\displaystyle=\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{Y}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))\cdot\text{Pr}(\mathbf{Y}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))
−Pr​(𝒜​(𝐗,𝐱)=y|𝐗∈(𝐎C−𝐎o))⋅Pr​(𝐗∈(𝐎C−𝐎o)).⋅Pr𝒜𝐗𝐱conditional𝑦𝐗subscript𝐎𝐶subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝐗subscript𝐎𝐶subscript𝐎𝑜\displaystyle\;-\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{X}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))\cdot\text{Pr}(\mathbf{X}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}-\mathbf{O}_{o})). (19)

Similarly, we have the following equation for any i≠y𝑖𝑦i\neq y:

pi′−pisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖′subscript𝑝𝑖\displaystyle p_{i}^{\prime}-p_{i} =Pr​(𝒜​(𝐘,𝐱)=i|𝐘∈(𝐎C′−𝐎o))⋅Pr​(𝐘∈(𝐎C′−𝐎o))absent⋅Pr𝒜𝐘𝐱conditional𝑖𝐘superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝐘superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′subscript𝐎𝑜\displaystyle=\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{x})=i|\mathbf{Y}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))\cdot\text{Pr}(\mathbf{Y}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))
−Pr​(𝒜​(𝐗,𝐱)=i|𝐗∈(𝐎C−𝐎o))⋅Pr​(𝐗∈(𝐎C−𝐎o)).⋅Pr𝒜𝐗𝐱conditional𝑖𝐗subscript𝐎𝐶subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝐗subscript𝐎𝐶subscript𝐎𝑜\displaystyle\;-\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{x})=i|\mathbf{X}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))\cdot\text{Pr}(\mathbf{X}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}-\mathbf{O}_{o})). (20)

Therefore, we can show:

py′−pi′superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑦′superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖′\displaystyle p_{y}^{\prime}-p_{i}^{\prime} =py−pi+(py′−py)−(pi′−pi)absentsubscript𝑝𝑦subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑦′subscript𝑝𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖′subscript𝑝𝑖\displaystyle=p_{y}-p_{i}+(p_{y}^{\prime}-p_{y})-(p_{i}^{\prime}-p_{i}) (21)

+[Pr​(𝒜​(𝐘,𝐱)=y|𝐘∈(𝐎C′−𝐎o))−Pr​(𝒜​(𝐘,𝐱)=i|𝐘∈(𝐎C′−𝐎o))]⋅Pr​(𝐘∈(𝐎C′−𝐎o))⋅delimited-[]Pr𝒜𝐘𝐱conditional𝑦𝐘superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝒜𝐘𝐱conditional𝑖𝐘superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝐘superscriptsubscript𝐎𝐶′subscript𝐎𝑜\displaystyle+\left[\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{Y}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))-\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{x})=i|\mathbf{Y}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))\right]\cdot\text{Pr}(\mathbf{Y}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}^{\prime}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))

Note that we have:

Pr​(𝒜​(𝐗,𝐱)=y|𝐗∈(𝐎C−𝐎o))−Pr​(𝒜​(𝐗,𝐱)=i|𝐗∈(𝐎C−𝐎o))≤1,Pr𝒜𝐗𝐱conditional𝑦𝐗subscript𝐎𝐶subscript𝐎𝑜Pr𝒜𝐗𝐱conditional𝑖𝐗subscript𝐎𝐶subscript𝐎𝑜1\displaystyle\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{x})=y|\mathbf{X}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))-\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{x})=i|\mathbf{X}\in(\mathbf{O}_{C}-\mathbf{O}_{o}))\leq 1, (24)

(25)

Therefore, based on (22) and that pysubscript𝑝𝑦p_{y} and pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} are integer multiplications of 1(nk)1binomial𝑛𝑘\frac{1}{{n\choose k}}, we have the following:

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 3

Based on the Clopper-Pearson method, for each testing example 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}, we have:

Pr(py^t¯≤Pr(𝒜(𝒮(𝐂,k),𝐱t)=y^t)∧p¯z^t≥Pr(𝒜(𝒮(𝐂,k),𝐱t)=i),∀i≠y^t)≥1−αd.\displaystyle\text{Pr}(\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}\leq\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C},k),\mathbf{x}_{t})=\hat{y}_{t})\land\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}\geq\text{Pr}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{C},k),\mathbf{x}_{t})=i),\forall i\neq\hat{y}_{t})\geq 1-\frac{\alpha}{d}. (66)

Therefore, for a testing example 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}, if our Algorithm 2 does not abstain for 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t}, the probability that it returns an incorrect certified security level is at most αd𝛼𝑑\frac{\alpha}{d}. Formally, we have the following:

Pr((∃𝐂′,M(𝐂′)≤m^t∗,h(𝐂′,𝐱t)≠y^t)|y^t≠ABSTAIN)≤αd.\displaystyle\text{Pr}((\exists\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*},h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})\neq\hat{y}_{t})|\hat{y}_{t}\neq\text{ABSTAIN})\leq\frac{\alpha}{d}. (67)

Therefore, we have the following:

Pr(∩𝐱t∈𝒟((∀𝐂′,M(𝐂′)≤m^t∗,h(𝐂′,𝐱t)=y^t)|y^t≠ABSTAIN))\displaystyle\quad\text{Pr}(\cap_{\mathbf{x}_{t}\in\mathcal{D}}((\forall\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*},h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})=\hat{y}_{t})|\hat{y}_{t}\neq\text{ABSTAIN})) (68)
=1−Pr(∪𝐱t∈𝒟((∃𝐂′,M(𝐂′)≤m^t∗,h(𝐂′,𝐱t)≠y^t)|y^t≠ABSTAIN))\displaystyle=1-\text{Pr}(\cup_{\mathbf{x}_{t}\in\mathcal{D}}((\exists\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*},h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})\neq\hat{y}_{t})|\hat{y}_{t}\neq\text{ABSTAIN})) (69)
≥1−∑𝐱t∈𝒟Pr((∃𝐂′,M(𝐂′)≤m^t∗,h(𝐂′,𝐱t)≠y^t)|y^t≠ABSTAIN)\displaystyle\geq 1-\sum_{\mathbf{x}_{t}\in\mathcal{D}}\text{Pr}((\exists\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*},h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})\neq\hat{y}_{t})|\hat{y}_{t}\neq\text{ABSTAIN}) (70)
≥1−d⋅αdabsent1⋅𝑑𝛼𝑑\displaystyle\geq 1-d\cdot\frac{\alpha}{d} (71)
=1−α.absent1𝛼\displaystyle=1-\alpha. (72)

We have (70) from (69) based on the Boole’s inequality.
